title: lamp light. Yes, yes
author: the box full of sun. No, no, girl. No, you do not have to kneel. There.

elements.text: PART ONE
Footsteps on gravel. A man with a slight French accent speaks.

So, it is you. Come in. I will not bite. Come, little jungle girl, come. Yes, yes, pull the canvas down behind you. See? You are quite safe. Why not sit yourself down here, in the lamp light. Yes, yes, by the box full of sun. No, no, girl. No, you do not have to kneel. There. Good. You told no one you were coming, no one saw you leave the camp fire? Good. Good. So, you want to see my magic, hah? You want to see my games. How about a shiny coin the air? Take it, it's yours. Pardon? Oh, on the head side. Yes, it is a fair likeness, is it not? Of course, I was younger then, and my chin was more pronounce. What? What? Another? Another trick for my little jungle princess?
Claps hands, bird chirps.

Oh, I wonder where that came from, huh? No, no, there's nothing up my sleeve. Farewell, little song bird. (sighs) But these are so easy. You know what I want, girl. Did you find it? No. Ah. Well, never mind, it's not so important now. Now then, you want to see some real magic, yes? I knew it. Very well, but you will have to move a little closer. A little closer still. There. Now, hold my gaze. Hold my gaze.
The girl gasps in pain.
No. No, do not struggle. Do not struggle. You wanted to see my magic. This is magic. This is real magic.
Charley! Charley! Come and see some real magic.
Magic?
Humour him.

Dear lady, h'allow me to h'introduce you to a polychromatic person of variegated vividness, a man of multiple and motley hue, the Eutermesan with the ever-changing epidermis. I give you C'Rizz the Colourful Chameleon!
I thank you!
Now, young lady, think of a colour. Any colour of the rainbow, any segment of the spectrum.
Pink.
Pink?
Pink, says the lady, and pink she shall have. (claps hands) How's that?
Like a dried up salmon mousse.
More pink, my opalescent associate.
More pink.
Straining noises.
If the wind changes, you'll keep that face.
Ta dah!
That's not pink, that's puce.
Ah, you made him blush, that's all. Green!
More straining noises.
He's so mauve. Vermilion!
Blue and yellow polka dots.
No, sorry.
Oh. Well, what kind of a spectacle is that? I was lead to expect an exhibition of
effortless exchange. To be transfixed by a tremendous tumult of transformation.
Shh.
That doesn't sound healthy.
It does. It sounds fantastic.
Do you want to ask?
No, you. I did it last time.
You sure?
When the Tressilion flagship disappeared into that spatial fracture. You know, the day before yesterday.
Oh, all right then. Doctor, what's happening?
Hmm?
I said, what's happening?
No, not like that. (clears throat, then pleading) Doctor, what's happening, Doctor?
That's good.
Practice, you see.
What's happening?
+ C'RIZZ: Yes.
Ah, um, well, you see, well, um, isn't it obvious?
+ C'RIZZ: No.
Blast. I was hoping one of you could tell me. Only joking. It's just, for a moment I could have sworn that the Tardis went into reverse.
And that's unusual.
You mean, in Time? Backwards in Time?
Or something very like it.
But that's impossible.

In a closed universe with no vortex to navigate, it's not just impossible, it's inconcievable. But I can taste it. It's there, in my gut, in my toes, down the nape of my neck. Only there's nothing there. Nothing.
That reminds me of Uncle Jacques. He lived in Cannes after the war and I used to visit him every summer. He taught me to speak French, and even eat frog's legs, which were pretty filthy, actually.
Is there a point to this story?
Unlikely. It is one of Charley's stories. Mind you, the south of France is lovely. Long walks down the Croisette, a quick jaunt down to Monaco.
Anyway, Uncle Jacques was a concert pianist, till he lost an arm at Passchendaele. He said that whenever he passed the Bechstein in the parlour, he felt the fingers on the hand he'd lost.
Is that what you think my instinct was? A phantom reflex, a spasm in a missing limb?
(alarmed) Doctor, what's that?
Oh, much better!
Up there, on the projector.
What, the blue moon hurtling straight towards us?
I think you'll find it's us hurtling straight towards it.
Depends on your perspective.
Can we not skip the debate? The point is, we're going to get squished by it whatever.
Nil desperandum, fair Charlotte. We may be drawn into its gravitational field, but all we have to do is programme a hasty materialisation. That's odd. I'll try again. Oh.
Now is not the time to tell us something's wrong with the Tardis.
There's nothing wrong, I think. She's refusing to let us land, that's all. What is it, old girl? Is there something down there you don't like?
That's the stratosphere breached.
I thought it was getting warmer. Of course, basic astrophysics tells us that as a moon, it shouldn't really have a stratosphere.
Perhaps someone should tell it that.
You're really going to have to materialise down there, old girl. Whatever it is can't be worse than crashing. Right.

Oh, for heaven's sake. Listen here, you dizzy cow of a Tardis. I Know there's no love lost between us, but now is really not the time to have one of your funny turns, or hissy fits, or whatever. It's not big, it's not clever, and no one's in the least bit impressed, so will you kindly stop mucking about and please, please, land.
Oh, I need something to prise this switch up.
Why?
Because I pushed it down rather too hard and it's stuck.
My moonstone.
Your what stone?
Hang on. There, use that.
Thank you.
That's pretty.
My father gave it too me.
Why moonstone?
Long story. By the look of it, we may not have much time.
Why not?
Because of that!
Oh, that doesn't look good.
It's not. That's us, burning up.
Well, I dare say it's better than crashing.
Depends on your perspective.
Heavy door opens.
Who's there?
It's me, my love, just seeing how you are. Today's the day.
Today? Where am I?
The chamber, of course. How much did you drink last night, then?
L'Da?
Yes?
This isn't possible.
What's not possible, my love?
To be here. Back here again, with you.
What are you talking about? Have you been dreaming?
Where's the Doctor? Where's Charlotte?
I'm sorry, you'll have to say that again.
I want to see the Doctor.
Oh. Oh, I see. Well, he can't come. Not now. I'm sorry.
Well, how about Charlotte?
What's a Charlotte? Oh, wait. Is ita person? Is it the man you met last night?
Charlotte isn't a man.
Oh?
She's a woman. A girl.
Oh.
A friend.
I thought I was your friend.
You're dead.
Don't be silly. We're getting married. Oh, come on, give us a smile.
What am I doing here?
Recuperating, I imagine. I hear that last night was a raucous occasion. I'm not sure I approve.
Approve? Approve of what?
Of my husband to be in about two hours cavorting and drinking like it was his last night alive. The Foundation tutors would be appalled. And if Guidance ever found out, well.
The Foundation?

You're still one of them, you know, and will remain so even after the marriage, more's the pity. Oh, C'Rizz, you've done your penance. Can't you leave the church behind? You've got a new life now. A life with me.
My penance?
You are being very strange, my love. I think I ought to go out, turn round three times, and then come back in and start again.
It's dark in here.
Of course it's dark. It's always dark in the Soul Chamber.
This is where I was before, before the Kromon.
The what? Are they anything to do with this Charlotte girl? Should I be jealous? More jealous, I mean. Obviously I'm already jealous. You had a raucous occasion and I wasn't invited, meany.
L'Da, listen to me. I don't know what's going on here, but this can't be real.
Why not?

Because you are dead. Twenty minutes into our marriage ceremony, insectoid spaceships arrived, directed here by an alien race called the Divergents. They opened fire. Those of us that survived were carted off to their biospheres. Eutermesans, Darlots, Oroogs, even the cattle.
I see. And what else have you been dreaming? Where does this Charlotte woman, sorry, girl, fit in?
Well, she doesn't. Not yet. She and the Doctor save me, take me away.
And do they save me? Are we bound together by love, freedom fighters against the invading Kromon, was it?
No. No, you died. I, I killed you.
Nice. If you're going to have pre-wedding jitters, you might at least have a fantasy where you get shot of me without actually killing me. I could get quite put off, you know.
Unless. Unless it was a dream, a premonition. In which case this is a second chance.
For what?
Look, my love, we must go, get away from here. Wait. I thought you said you'd seen the Doctor.
Well, yes. Doctor R'Tullen will be one of the ushers, unless he's decided the wedding's off. A not entirely unreasonable assumption, since he's not been able to find you all morning.
Not R'Tullen, the Doctor. Tall, bipedal, pale skin, shaggy hair?
Hair? Why would a man have hair? Oh, how revolting.
Something's wrong.
I'll say it is. You're still drunk.
No, I mean I. L'Da, let me tell you something.
Go on.
I'm not the person you think I am.
Doctor? C'Rizz? Hello? (echoes) No, nothing. Just a big dark (pause) room? Yes, it feels like an inside. Hello? Definitely inside. Bit of an echo, so not much in the way of furniture.
A big, empty room, perhaps.
Yes, I think so. Mother?
Hello, Lottie.
I suppose I should be surprised to see you.
But you're not?
No. Been around with the Doctor too long now. Not much left to surprise me.
Oh well, that makes things easier, then.
This is either a dream, or you're some sort of holographic projection created by the Tardis.
Goodness, what strange words. Tardis and holographic? Isn't that some sort of pencil?

Why are you here, Mother? I mean, it's not that I'm not pleased to see you. Far from it, in fact. But since I'm living in a pocket universe set apart from everything and everyone I've ever known, you can't actually be here, can you.
So what am I, then? A waking dream, an illusion? Why? For what purpose?
I know. You're a spirit guide. Oh, that must be it. I've died and you're taking me to heaven.
(laughs) Father Michael would be so pleased to hear you finally acknowledge the existence of an afterlife.

According to the Doctor, I died not that long ago. Didn't see heaven, no choirs of angels, no big pearly gates, no man with a long white beard offering me wings. God and afterlives don't feature very highly on my list of probables any more, Mother. Sorry.
Oh well, he'd be rather less thrilled to hear you say that.

It's an interesting thought, though, isn't it? I mean, I've seen above the clouds. I've witnessed the birth and death of a universe. I've seen a million different worlds, met a billion different people
I've told you a thousand times, Lottie. You simply mustn't exaggerate.
Life and death on such a scale that it no longer holds any meaning.
Not sure I understand.

I met a most unpleasant man once. A spy from South Africa. He tried to kill me. I mean, really kill me. But he died. I saw him die. Watched him falling away from an airship. Falling away until he became a speck too small to think of as a living, breathing person. He had a mother too.
And?

He died. Years of his life building towards the ultimate pointlessness of a violent death. He must have grown up with family, friends, schoolmates, worked hard, passed exams, learnt to walk, to talk, to become a boy, a youth, and then a man. All that effort, all that time and love that had gone into making him the man he was on the day I met him. And when he died, I was relieved. As I said, he was trying to kill me.
Strikes me, Lottie, that you've had a beastly time of it.

After a while, I found I could cope with death. The Doctor and I, we'd meet people and it became almost expected that some of them would drop away, die violent or pointless deaths. Really didn't take that long before it ceased to touch me.
But it affected you at first.

Oh, yes. Sleep. I couldn't go to sleep without seeing their faces. But after a while, I forgot them all. Oh, I can recall the odd names, people I liked, people I didn't, people who meant nothing to me one way or another. How awful that I've become so desensitised to death, that I simply don't care.
What made you think about this?
You, being here. You see, you're dead. Of that I'm sure. I'm not entirely sure where I am in relative time to Earth, but I know the chances of it being the 1930s right now are infinitesimally small.
So either I've long since faded from memory or I've not yet been born.
Either way, you aren't you.
Well, you're probably right.
That said, it's awfully nice to see you. I still see his face, you know.
Who?

That first one. The South African. Huh, I can't even remember his name. But I can always picture his face, screaming as he dropped away, knowing he was incapable of stopping himself but still hoping against hope that somehow he'd be saved.
Well, we all believe that we should be immortal. No one can ever quite accept they'll die, even though they know they will.
Well, not me. Not any more. No next life. One life, make it worthwhile.
And do you feel you've lived yours to the full? Got out of it everything you wanted?
Oh gosh, yes. I wouldn't change a thing. I've so enjoyed myself, and I do believe we've done some good, the Doctor and I.
You've done some good on your own, you know, just by being you.
I should hope so, but I'm not sure what.
Well then, come with me. Let me show you something.
You're scaring me, my love.
You believe I'm your husband to be. You believe that very soon I'm going to put aside my devotion to the Foundation and join you in a new life.
It had occured to me, yes.
That me died a long time ago.
I don't understand.
This can't be real. It's not a dream, I've not been taken back in Time
Time?

How easily the word comes now. I don't quite yet grasp the concept, but I get the broad idea. Oh, but it doesn't matter. I'm older, more experienced than the man you fell in love with. I've seen so much.
In your dreams, yes?
No, in reality. This is the dream.
I'm going to fetch Guidance. I think you need to talk to him.
He can't help me. Not Guidance, not the Church, not even you. L'Da, I no longer belong here. I can't keep hoping for my old life back.
Why not? What's wrong with it?
Nothing. Nothing at all, but it's not mine any longer.
Strong breeze.
Why is it that all my dreams bring me back here?
Where are we?
Don't you know?
Well, of course not. This is your subconscious we're exploring, not mine.
RAF Cardington, where it all began. And there, the pride of the air fleet
The R101. Flames.
Sorry?
Oh, I'm not sure why I said that. I had a sudden fear of fire.
Well, that doesn't surprise me. You see, here was where I. Oh, look!
What a very smart uniform. Who is he?
A boy I knew. A steward called Simon Murchford.
His significance?
Significance?
Yes. Why him?
He's the reason I'm here. I took his place on the R101.
So, had you not run away from school, he would have been aboard this airship of yours when it crashed. He would have died in the blaze.
Well, yes. Yes, I suppose so.
Excuse me. This is a restricted zone.
Sorry, Simon.
Er, have we met? You!
Who? Er, me. Yes, we were just leaving. Bye!
Hold on.
Charlotte, don't be so rude. Good afternoon to you, young man. I've not had the pleasure.
No, and neither have I, missus.
I beg your pardon?

Well, ask your girl. Last night in the Hare and Hounds, she got me steaming drunk. Spiked my drinks, she did. This morning I woke up, no bag, no uniform, nothing. The new kit came from stores, only now they'll dock my pay.
Oh, Simon, I'm sorry. I just wanted to take your place, go on the adventure, see Karachi and all the points in between.
It didn't work out though, did it. Where's my stuff, missy?
On board. Oh, it's too much to explain.
Oh, the hell with you. It's bad enough already. Damned if I'll let you miss my embarkation and get me on a charge.
Oh, Simon. Simon, please don't go. Please, just listen. Last night, wnen we talked, you said you wanted to travel.
That's right. See the world, broaden the mind and that. You said the same.
Yes, but you're a boy, man, I mean, whatever. That gives you opportunities I never had.
A posh girl like you? Pull the other one, missy, it's got bells on.
If you go on the R101, Simon, you'll never see those things. Please, don't board.
Sorry, sweet thing. You're nice and all, but I needs the money. Folks like me, we don't get your chances.
What chances?
Says the spoiled little rich girl.
Now listen here, young man.

Oh, sorry, missus. No disrespect to you, but I've seen her kind before. Nice girls flirting with rough boys for a giggle, for the danger. Well, sorry, sweetheart, but you can get yourself back to your nice big house with your servants and your gardeners. Where I come from, there's six of us live in two rooms, you know. If I want to get out of that, I'll need money or class. Well, I'll never have class, but if I can get meself some cash, who knows. Goodbye, missy. Save yourself for some chinless wonder who'll give you everything you want. You and me, we won't meet again.
No. No, we won't. Goodbye, and good luck.
Don't need luck, missy. Top workmanship in that beauty. We'll be in Isma@lia before we know it. Good day to you, missus.
Footsteps.
Well, he's almost charming, I suppose.
He's right, though. I took away his livelihood. His father hadn't worked since '26, he said.

My dear, you saved his life. If he'd been aboard that airship instead of you, I doubt the Doctor would have whisked him out of danger on the back of a flying reptile. No, shifty eyes. What sort of a companion would he have made?
But did I save him? He's boarding anyway, even though another me's on the airship too.
Something will happen to change that. Well, it must have done. You went, he didn't.
I'd like to leave now, Mother. I don't see the point of, point of.
Lottie, are you feeling all right?
Reliving.
Charlotte!
Thud.
Church bells pealing.
C'Rizz, it's the church bells. We're going to be late.
For what?
Our wedding, stupid. Oh please, come on.
What's the point? Look, any moment now, the Kromon will attack, and most of our
friends and family will be dead. The wedding can't happen.
Listen, you. I've been waiting three years for today. I'm not going to be put off because you've had a nightmare.

It's not a dream, L'Da. This is. All this, and being back here with you. The Divergents whisked us and the Kromon off to another planet because they want to experiment on the Doctor. None of this matters!
Oh, well, if our wedding doesn't happen because of this Doctor friend of yours, I shall have words with him, let me tell you.
But he's not responsible.
You just said he is. Our wedding is cancelled when the Kromon attack because of him. My death occurs because of him.
That's not fair. It's not his fault. Well, not exactly.
Yes, exactly. If he hadn't turned up, none of this would have happened. If he'd stayed out of this universe, stayed away, we'd be happily married. No Kromon, no metamorphosis, nothing.
How do you know all of this?
It's all his fault! Find a way to stop it happening. Please!
L'Da, I love you. I love you so much.
Good. Good. I love you too. But I'm scared now. Scared because you're so sure we can never be together. Never.
I wonder. I wonder if
Screams outside.
You're too late! You're too late! The Kromon are coming! The Kromon are here!
Energy weapons fire.
No, not again. Please, not again.
[OC]: It must have done. He went, you didn't.
[OC]: I'd like to leave now, Mother.
Charley gasps for breath.
[OC]: I don't see the point of
[OC]: Lottie, are you feeling all right?
[OC]: Reliving.
Regular beep of a heart monitor.

No. Oh, no, no, no, little Charley. Can't have you dying. Not when there's so much suffering yet to be had. Let's just see if I can't. There, that's better. Let's see now. (keyboard) Charlotte. Charlotte, my dear, are you
Charlotte, my dear, are you feeling better now? You look like you need a glass of water.
Oh, Mother? Oh, Mother, I felt like I was. Well, I thought I was going someplace else. Why am I still dreaming of Cardington?
You're the one who keeps bringing us back here. Something you want us to see, perhaps?
Someone's coming.
He's going jolly fast.
Should we hide, do you think?
Why ever should we want to do that?
Bicycle stops.
Good evening, ladies.
Oh, good evening, Reverend.
Oh. Can I ask, should I know you?
But
I don't think so.

Ah, good. Oh, sorry, that sounded off. New Chaplain, you see. The last fellow, Townsend, very popular, I'm told, well, he toddled off somewhere before I arrive. Never got the chance to meet and greet, make my introductions.
(sotto) It's him.
(sotto) Who?
(sotto) Look at him.
Murchford. Reverend Murchford.
We're Catholics, not C of E.
Just like your father. Forgive my daughter, Vicar. Pollard, Lady Louisa Pollard.
(sotto) Oh. Well, in that case. (normal) May I ask the Vicar a question?
Well, of course.
Isn't your first name Simon?
It is. Hold on a minute. Are you sure we've not met?
(sotto) Oh God.
I knew a girl called Pollard once. Pretty young thing. Looked a bit like you.
Oh, only a bit? Coincidence, surely.
Well then, how do you know who I am?
Er, this is going to be difficult.
Your mother, perhaps. Or your sister?
No, not my sister. My mother, yes. That's who it was. Charlotte, my mother. And this is my grandmother.
Grandmother. Thank you so much.
1930 it was. Just down the road from here, yes?
Possibly.
Well, I take it that since you're here, she didn't go.
Go?
On the airship. The 101. Funny, that's what made me want to come back to this neck of the woods. Survivor's guilt, they call it.
But you must be glad that you didn't go.
What?
Well, you'd have died.
Oh, yes. Well, wouldn't have had to go through the war, though. Lost a lot of good friends.
How much do you remember about me, my mother?

Ask her yourself. That night in the Hare and Hounds, she got me steaming drunk. Spiked my drinks, she did. Next morning, I woke up, no bag, no uniform, no nothing. Couldn't get a kit from stores. Chose to go on a charge rather than have my pay docked.

Oh, Simon, I'm sorry. I, she just wanted to take your place, go on the adventure. See Isma@lia and Karachi, and everything in between. Please understand that, as a man, boy, whatever, you had those chances. To see the world, to travel. My mother never would have had otherwise.

I'm sure your mother was lovely to you. You're very nice. But I'm glad I didn't meet her again. All that she cost me and then to opt out of going anyway. Typical. Still, that was a long time ago. Things move on. Well, look at me now. And I think it was missing the flight that helped me find my path.
To God?

That's right. So many died in France, I found myself thinking I'd been saved for a purpose. I suppose there's a reason for everything in life. Anyway, must dash. Summer F@te doesn't run itself, you know. Goodbye.
Goodbye.
So all things considered, you must now be rather pleased that you went with the Doctor.
I never regretted it. Not once.
Hmm. Well, we'll see.
What was that?
Er, nothing, my dear. Just thinking how proud I am of you.
Nonsense. Utter rot. You're not my mother. You've nothing to be proud of.
Now Charlotte, please.

Oh, nice try. Oh, very good. You almost had me for a moment. But this has been tried before. Someone's playing with my mind. I know that you, Murchford, Cardington, none of it's real. This is someone giving me back what they think I want more than anything else, knowing that I can't have it. To go home again. Oh, and I know who.
Who what?
Oh, come on, you miserable little thing. Where are you? In my head or actually here?
Why are you yelling your head off at the sky?
Oh, you'll see.
Well, nothing's happening. Look, I'm going to get that nice Vicar back. I think he needs to talk to you.
I'm perfectly all right. I just need to find him!
Reverend Murchford?
The Kro'Ka!
Oh, Lordy. And who is he, then?

A schemer, a manipulator. The servant of the creatures who run this ridiculous universe, the Divergents. Above all, he's a complete fraud, a malicious piece of excrement in dire need of damn good hiding!
Oh, fantastic. The girl's figured it out, my lord. Well, almost.
The Eutermesan?
Not a clue. But then I always told the Divergents they were wasting their time with that lot. Hardly a brain cell between the lot of them.
And yet this one elected to travel with the Doctor, broaden his mind.
None of them seem to have worked out the truth yet. About me, I mean. And you. Our arrangement.
Good. And what about the Doctor?

Ah, yes. Wait till you see where I've put him. I should have liked to have stayed to watch, but I needed to install the Dreamweavers we stole from Caerdroia in here, as you requested. I only have two pairs of hands, my lord.
You can have as many pairs of hands as you choose, Kro'Ka. Don't play games with me. You know what happened last time.
Yes, my lord. Took three weeks for the swelling to go down.
Enough. We must push ahead, Kro'Ka. No more tests, no more questions. Time to talk face to face, the girl first.
There's a wind getting up. We should find some shelter.
Something's happening. I can feel it.
What do you mean?
Can't you sense it? Oh, no, no, of course not. You're not real. You're just doing whatever the Kro'Ka wants you to, tells you to.
Now don't be silly, Lottie. You should apologise, you know.
Whoosh!
No, dear lady. It is I who should apologise.
You? What are you doing here?
Why, Miss Pollard, I'm the reason the Doctor entered this little chunk of space and T. Well, space. Didn't you know? He's been searching for me, and I in turn have been searching for you.
Why me?
I have a proposition to put to you. One that could truly reunite you with this delightful lady beside you now.
And who exactly are you?
Lady Pollard, allow me to introduce myself. My name is Rassilon. And despite appearances to the contrary, your daughter's mind is entirely under my domination.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
KEEP: So, it is you. Come in. I will not bite. Come, little jungle girl, come. Yes, yes, pull the canvas down behind you. See? You are quite safe. Why not sit yourself down here, in the lamp light. Yes, yes, by the box full of sun. No, no, girl. No, you do not have to kneel. There. Good. You told no one you were coming, no one saw you leave the camp fire? Good. Good. So, you want to see my magic, hah? You want to see my games. How about a shiny coin the air? Take it, it's yours. Pardon? Oh, on the head side. Yes, it is a fair likeness, is it not? Of course, I was younger then, and my chin was more pronounce. What? What? Another? Another trick for my little jungle princess?
KEEP: Oh, I wonder where that came from, huh? No, no, there's nothing up my sleeve. Farewell, little song bird. (sighs) But these are so easy. You know what I want, girl. Did you find it? No. Ah. Well, never mind, it's not so important now. Now then, you want to see some real magic, yes? I knew it. Very well, but you will have to move a little closer. A little closer still. There. Now, hold my gaze. Hold my gaze.
KEEP: No. No, do not struggle. Do not struggle. You wanted to see my magic. This is magic. This is real magic.
DOCTOR: Charley! Charley! Come and see some real magic.
CHARLEY: Magic?
C'RIZZ: Humour him.
DOCTOR: Dear lady, h'allow me to h'introduce you to a polychromatic person of variegated vividness, a man of multiple and motley hue, the Eutermesan with the ever-changing epidermis. I give you C'Rizz the Colourful Chameleon!
C'RIZZ: I thank you!
DOCTOR: Now, young lady, think of a colour. Any colour of the rainbow, any segment of the spectrum.
CHARLEY: Pink.
C'RIZZ: Pink?
DOCTOR: Pink, says the lady, and pink she shall have. (claps hands) How's that?
